newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek shares trade firmer but index settles lower.
newsitem.headline: Greek shares trade firmer but index settles lower.

text.p: Greek construction stocks along with small-caps and banks traded firmer but industrials fell and the benchmark index settled with minor losses on low volume with brokers expecting equities to snap out of their sideways phase.

"Trading volume remains low and the market is holding at the low 900s in a wait-and-see attitude. But after a prolonged sideways phase stocks are likely to break out on the upside if the ongoing audits of brokers do not bring any negative surprises," said broker Iakovos Diamantopoulos at Hermes Brokerage.
Meanwhile, farmers continued a five-day blockade of major highways protesting against Greece's austere 1997 budget.

They are demanding lower diesel fuel prices, cuts in the VAT tax on farm equipment, rescheduling of 1.3 billion drachmas of debt by farm cooperatives to state Agricultural Bank and higher price supports especially for cotton.
Greece cut the marker 12-month T-bill rate by 50 basis points down to 11.50 percent in December. The issue came to market on Monday and sold well.

The Athens general share index closed down 0.12 percent or 1.12 points lower at 916.71 from Monday's 917.83 close after opening at 917.75. Turnover was 2.41 billion drachmas on volume of 1.8 million shares.
